snippet: With relatively few lower-court appointments, President Obama has made less of an ideological imprint on the judiciary than liberals hoped and conservatives feared.
abstract: Pres Obama is set to end his term with dozens fewer lower-court appointments than his immediate predecessors, and will likely leave less of a lasting ideological imprint on the judiciary than many liberals had hoped for and conservatives had feared; record stems in part from a decision to make judicial nominations a lower political priority, along with heavy partisan opposition from Senate Republicans.
lead_paragraph: With relatively few lower-court appointments, President Obama has made less of an ideological imprint on the judiciary than liberals hoped and conservatives feared.

headline.seo: Obama Lags on Filling Seats in the Judiciary
headline.main: Obama Lags on Judicial Picks, Limiting His Mark on Courts
headline.print_headline: Obama Limits Lasting Stamp On the Courts
